title: Philippines president Rodrigo Duterte reveals rare autoimmune disease which causes droopy eyelid
text:
Philippines president Rodrigo Duterte has revealed he suffers from a rare autoimmune disease, with allies playing down concern for his health today.

Duterte, 74, said he suffers from myasthenia gravis, which causes one of his eyelids to droop, at an appearance before the Philippine community on Saturday night during a visit to Russia.

'One of my eyes is smaller. It roams on its own,' he said, according to a transcript released Sunday by his office. 'That's myasthenia gravis. It's a nerve malfunction. I got it from my grandfather.'

Speculation has swirled around his health since he took office, but senior aide Senator Christopher 'Bong' Go said 'it's nothing serious,' adding the president is 'conscious of his health'.

President Rodrigo Duterte, 74, said he suffered from myasthenia gravis, which causes one of his eyelids to droop, at an appearance before the Philippine community on Saturday night during a visit to Russia (pictured: speaking to an official in Beijing in August)

Indeed, Duterte has previously quipped he'll be dead before the next presidential term in 2022.

What is myasthenia gravis? Symptoms: droopy eyelids

double vision

weak facial muscles

difficulty with chewing and swallowing

slurred speech

weak limbs, neck

shortness of breath and occasionally serious breathing problems Prognosis It typically affects the whole body, spreading from the eyes and face over months or years. However, in around 20 percent of people it is localised to the eye muscles (ocular myasthenia). Treatment helps control symptoms and it is rarely life-threatening and does not impact significantly on life expectancy. Source: NHS

Duterte's ailments were to be expected because of his age, but they have not stopped his work and would not be a political issue, said Earl Parreno of the Institute of Political and Electoral Reforms.

Since his 2016 election, Duterte's popularity remains at a level that other politicians would 'die for', Parreno said.

With an approval rating of about 80% and a super-majority in Congress, there is little prospect of an opposition challenge to his authority on health or any other grounds.

Opposition politicians contacted by Reuters declined or did not respond to request for comment on the health issue.

Known for a busy schedule and long speeches - often up to three a day - several disappearances from public view have fuelled rumours about Duterte's declining health, but the government has repeatedly dismissed any suggestion of a problem.

Panelo said he did not think that the president's latest illness was serious, adding it didn't get in the way of his 'punishing schedule' in Russia.

'I'm even amazed how he was able to survive this Russian trip,' Panelo said in an interview with ANC news channel.

hilippine President Rodrigo Duterte (left) attends a wreath laying ceremony at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Moscow on Friday

There is no cure for myasthenia gravis, which causes muscle weakness, but treatment can help relieve symptoms.

Dr Jose Paciano Reyes, a fellow at the Philippine Neurological Association, said if a person had ocular myasthenia for more than two years, the chances were that weakness and fatigue would not spread to other muscle groups.

Duterte was the oldest person to be elected president in the Philippines since World War Two.

Late last year he said he had tested negative for cancer, and he blamed his long exposure to the sun when the public took notice of discoloration in his face.

The Constitution provides for the public to be told of the state of health of a president, if serious.

If a sitting president dies, is permanently disabled or removed through impeachment, the vice-president serves the remainder of a six-year, single term.

Russian President Vladimir Putin (right) shakes hands with Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte during their meeting in the Black Sea resort of in Sochi, Russia on Thursday

Vice-President Leni Robredo, a leader of the opposition, was elected separately in 2016.

Duterte's known ailments include back issues, migraines due to nerve damage after a motorcycle accident and Barrett's oesophagus, which affects his throat. He also suffers from Buerger's disease, caused by heavy smoking in his younger days.

Duterte is known for an unorthodox work schedule that typically starts in the mid-afternoon and can go on well beyond midnight.
